awd_titl_txt: CAREER: The Impact of Poverty Mapping on the Geography of Development
awd_abstract_narration:
For decades, the eradication of poverty has been a primary goal of policy-makers. Poverty mapping is an important tool that experts contend can enable institutions to more effectively and efficiently target poverty interventions. This project investigates the production, use and impact of poverty mapping. The project investigates the forms of measurement, the types of knowledge and expertise mobilized, and how these maps may capture or mask layers of scaled politics regarding the poor. The research bridges the gap between geographers who use Geographic Information Science (GIS) to advance policy interventions and those who critically analyze poverty and governance using qualitative and contextual methods. This project contributes to the education of university students on both these tools and these critical questions of poverty governance, and builds capacity in how local people can understand such assessments or interventions taking place in their own localities. The research also has broad implications for policy-makers and NGOs engaged in poverty identification and policy alleviation of this problem. Together, researchers and participants will produce maps of interventions that could be used by local stakeholders, policy-makers, development practitioners, and governments of multiple scales to understand the impact of geographical targeting areas in most need of immediate assistance. An online, open-source map of development interventions, infographics and a k-12 teaching module will expand the impact of the research to a wider public. The research creates a framework for analyzing the spatial patterns of successful intervention and remaining challenges resulting from the geographical targeting of poverty.

The project is informed by relational poverty, critical cartography and actor network theory; it approaches poverty mapping as a network consisting of a tool, a set of actors involved in its production, and specific sites and subjects of intervention. The project analyzes the field of poverty interventions and the spatial patterns associated with this technique of poverty alleviation. Using multi-sited research and case studies from North Africa, the researchers will employ oral surveys, interviews, ethnographic village assessments and spatial analyzes to generate a localized and contextualized understanding of poverty. The research will reveal the aspects of poverty that may have hidden behind aggregate indicators, highlight how the spatial patterns associated with poverty mapping act as an intervention, and illustrate how poverty reduction strategies impact the geography of development.

por.por_cntn:
The United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) call for measurable and comparable data and metrics to lift the world?s 1.2 billion poorest out of poverty by 2030. Poverty maps are just one of the many tools employed in this effort. This project examined poverty mapping as a network consisting of a tool, a set of actors involved in its production, and specific sites and subjects of intervention. The goal of the project was to understand how poverty mapping is framed as a technocratic intervention, used as a political instrument, and experienced as a mechanism of governance. The research team conducted participatory mapping workshops as both a method of inquiry and way to broaden the impact of the research.

The project included both quantitative and qualitative methodologies and required multi-year, multi-sited field-based research on the impact of poverty mapping on development across various field sites in Morocco and France. The research examined the forms of measurement, the nature of knowledge and expertise mobilized, and the political impacts of poverty maps as a mode of governance on the people and places labeled as the poorest of the poor. While the technocrats who produce poverty maps argue that the tool is an objective, apolitical and efficient way to allocate resources, the results of this research indicate that the map and its associated interventions are highly politicized.

The geographical targeting of poverty in large part does not accurately reflect accessibility as an obstacle to development, and the use of the poverty map can reproduce existing inequalities at a local scale. Remoteness was determined to be one of the most important factors related to poverty in the case study region of Morocco. A remoteness index was created to measure this variable and policy recommendations were made on how to create new satellite centers based on the combination of the new accessibility index, population size, and other variables.

The data elucidates the contextual aspects of poverty hidden behind poverty maps and aggregate indicators, the spatial patterns associated with the poverty map, and how they mask layers of inequality that get buried beneath development interventions. The research makes vital contributions to understanding the ?data revolution? implemented as part of the SDGs and bridges an important gap between the technical side of producing poverty maps and the critical work of unpacking them. The work engages with debates about poverty measurement and inequality, remoteness and accessibility, how to measure access to social services including health and education, and patterns of rural and urban development.

The project supported graduate and undergraduate students, giving them an opportunity to participate in various aspects of the research process, including data collection, participatory mapping workshops, engaging with open-source data, data analysis and the logistics of research. Trainings were conducted with local associations on how to use mapping in their own communities. A website and infographics were created to disseminate the research to a broader audience. Curriculum modules were produced for K-12 teachers and interactive workshops were conducted with small groups of educators to teach critical development studies before college. The project introduced a new methodology for measuring accessibility in relation to poverty and geographic variables. It has developed policy recommendations for how to better reach the most remote populations and developed participatory mapping workshops as both a method of inquiry and a method for developing data on places that are data poor.
